T1566.name: Phishing
T1566.description: Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems.

T1059.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
T1059.description: Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands.

T1055.name: Process Injection
T1055.description: Adversaries may inject code into processes to evade detection.

T1003.name: OS Credential Dumping
T1003.description: Adversaries may attempt to dump credentials to obtain account login information.

T1083.name: File and Directory Discovery
T1083.description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories to find information.

T1071.name: Application Layer Protocol
T1071.description: Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols.

T1041.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
T1041.description: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an existing C2 channel.

T1070.name: Indicator Removal on Host
T1070.description: Adversaries may delete or alter generated artifacts on a host system.

T1210.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
T1210.description: Adversaries may exploit remote services to achieve lateral movement.

T1018.name: Remote System Discovery
T1018.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of other systems by IP address.

Initial Access.description: Techniques used to gain an initial foothold within a network

Execution.description: Techniques that result in adversary-controlled code running on a local or remote system

Defense Evasion.description: Techniques adversaries use to avoid detection throughout their compromise

Credential Access.description: Techniques for stealing credentials like account names and passwords

Discovery.description: Techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network

Command and Control.description: Techniques that adversaries may use to communicate with systems under their control

Exfiltration.description: Techniques that adversaries may use to steal data from your network

Lateral Movement.description: Techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network
